ratings.comment: Pretty poor lecturer. As someone who's never taken any kind of statistics course before, I spent many lectures staring confused at the board and I have taken 3rd year calculus and am fairly good at math. He doesn't really explain anything, just does examples of a few problems on the board. TAs are very unhelpful so no saving there.

Many people did not like him but I loved his teaching style. He gives examples during class and expected you to do homework based off lecture but nothing was easy. I went to the help desk (open M-F 9-4) one day a week for an hour at a time and got 100% on most homework assignments. Go to office hours if you need help, Don wants to help.

Don is a really nice guy and he is well intentioned, but his teachings are poor. He is very smart and usually lectures with no use of notes, but never really explains anything he does. He mostly just writes on the board and expects the class to know what it means. Homework doesn't correlate to the class hardly at all. He loves unfair T/F questions.
super nice professor, easy class, homework wasnt too bad

You get a full note sheet front and back for each of the four exams, none of which are cumulative. The first exam is all review, and they get progressively harder. He is very smart and often lectures without his notes, which results in lots of mathematical errors. He's a funny guy who tries joking around. Grades tests  generously but homework hard.

Pretty good. The class had 3 projects in R which are pretty much grade boosts but you have to put some work into it. The homework takes awhile. His lectures are pretty good and he actually writes out words to help you understand the material. His worst aspect is he is terribly disorganized. Tons of typos and almost no space to do work on the exams

There are six+ hours a week of homework, and Porter is pathetically disorganized.  However, the lectures are fairly straightforward and the exams come almost straight from the lectures so getting an A isn't too tough.

Very knowledgeable about the subject and has a positive attitude that makes statistical experiment design a bit less dull. The exams and grading are very fair, but there's quite a bit of homework. Major drawback: He doesn't know any R, so you'll get no help from him (nor the TA, nor the textbook) when it comes to actually doing the work.

Don was an alright professor. His exams were not bad, and lecture was fine. I personally learned a lot better from the book and TA, so I stopped going to lecture and did better on the exams. Class is an easy A. Straightforward projects and homework graded basically on completion. Don is very scatter-brained, so be ready for poor organization.

Don is the man. He's hilarious in a completely weird way and makes lectures as enjoyable as possible. You get a notecard for every exam, the projects (while obnoxious) are straightforward, and the homework (while boring) is easy enough. An A should not be an issue if you make a good notecard.

Best option for intro stats by far. Straightforward about his expectations and his exams follow the homework pretty closely. Projects can be a little obnoxious but are mostly straightforward. Non-cumulative finale. Take Stats with Porter, he's like your Grandpa but better at math.

Class was really easy. Weekly quizzes with a notecard, no exams (except the OPTIONAL final), homework which is basically graded on completion, and projects which are done almost entirely for you by the TAs. Plus, Don is really fun and makes class interesting!

Don is super awesome. Its a generally engaging lecture, regardless of it being about 300 people, which is talent in itself. He's super helpful, clear and knows what he is doing. The class itself is quite easy as well and material is basic. Weekly quizzes WITH a notecard and final optional. Could you ask for more?
Class was extremely easy just have to study for the quizzes and no tests with optional final. Lecture really does not help though so just read the book.
He's super nice and pretty hilarious. Weekly homework and quizzes require a little time, but there are no mid terms and the final is optional. Easy class.

Prof Porter is an eccentric guy. He thinks he is hilarious, which I thought made him really entertaining. No tests, only homework, quizzes, easy projects (avg was a 98%) and optional final. Definitely one of the easier stats classes at the university.

This guy isn't quite all there in the head. Lectures are basically pointless to go to because he just rambles on and on and is very unclear. Quizzes aren't bad if you study. Overall, its not that hard to do well, but this guy is a nut job.
Porter makes this class extremely easy. Weekly quizzes that are manageable with studying and an optional final which is nice come end of the semester.

This guy is AWESOME! I totally recommend taking this class, he clearly explains his material and its really easy to get an A. If you get above a 95% at the end of the semester you dont have to take the final.

He has 12 weekly quizzes, 2 of them you can drop. I personally would have preffered test based instead, his quizzes were tricky. Final is not too bad, but I heard that other professors are much more interesting and easier to learn from.

Dedicated professor who loves what he does. Stats is boring but he makes it as interesting and applicable as possible. No exams. 12 weekly quizzes, drop lowest 2, can use a notecard on each. 3 easy Excel projects. Don't have to take the final if you have a 95% on quizzes and projects.Do all of the weekly HW (not turned in) and will ace the quizzes.
One of the best professors I've ever had.  Puts his heart into teaching during lecture and is friendly and helpful outside of lecture.

Porter is a great teacher who makes lecture interesting. Weekly quizzes (can drop lowest 2) and 4 projects. if you receive a 95% or better in the course you don't have to take the final exam, which is awesome. Very flexible with rescheduling tests and stuff that are missed for university sponsored events such as athletics.

Great teacher. Enjoys teaching and coming to class. Quizzes are easy and he always goes over examples in lecture versus just giving equations. you get a notecard and he even has an automatic A option if you can get a 95% before taking the final
Great Professor. He made the material easy to understand.

Don Porter is awesome.  He is very clear and makes a lot of bad jokes which I enjoyed.  In my class we had weekly quizzes and you could drop two.  The quizzes were very straightforward.  There were also three projects on Excel that were kinda tricky but were graded generously.

He is very knowledgeable and pretty funny too. Going to lecture can be substituted by reading the book. Weekly quizzes are no problem if you did either of those things. Homework is completely optional; I never did it. I got a B despite skipping a lot of lectures
Very easy class, but well taught
Dry material, but a funny guy. Weekly quizzes, but no midterms.

Quizzes once a week.  One exam, final.  The material covered per exam is predictable and he allows cheat sheets/notecards. Not to mention, he is an alternative option to Bates.  Highly suggest taking Porter for stats.

12 quiz, drop lowest 2. just one final exam, you can bring an A4 paper. Final exam is the same as quiz, super easy. Plus 4 projects, you have no problem to earn an A. If you get a 95%, you don't have to take the final. What a good course! Don is funny and helpful. He made some mistakes, and give you 2 extra points if you point out mistakes in HW

Professor porter is pretty comical or at least attempts to be most of the time. But seriously he's easy to follow and lectures flow quick. He makes it possible for you to get a good grade somehow because even if you don't understand the math part very much there are still projects that you can earn easy points on.Textbook is horrible though!
pretty easy class. one quiz a week, if you have an A before the final, you don't need to take it. hw is optional

Genuinely enjoyable for being a statistics class. Porter is entertaining and exempts you from the final if you have above a 95%, which is about a tenth of the class gets. If you've taken a stats class before, you won't have to study much. Allows notecards on quizzes and exams. Stresses applying concepts over memorization.

I HATED this class!  Porter was scatter-brained, leaping from one subject to the next it confused me.  Also, he also didn't always follow his policies that close, example having subject on a quiz that was meant for the next one.

Don is not clear in lecture and goes through material really quickly. He does not go over what he expects on exams which makes them extremely difficult.  The only grades however are easy projects and quizzes. If you have above a 95% before the final, you do not have to take the test.

I hate math, and sometimes Porter can make no sense at all (that's why the book is quite helpful) but damn, this old guy can be effing hilarious sometimes.  Showing us the squirrel he shot in his nightgown, throwing markers behind his back.  If anything, go to lecture for the entertainment.
He is a goofball.  Thinks he is really funny.  Showed a picture in class of him shooting a squirrel in a bath robe.  A real character.  Has a unique look to him.  Could imagine him in****...
not a very experienced teacher but very approchable and cares about his students.  class is more procedural than conceptual but prof solicits student input.

Only two exams which sucked, but that might change. Open to suggestions. Good prof. Quizzes every week, so you have to keep up. randomly collects homework. Not too much work. Explains things throughly and slowly, so if you don't understand stats, this class is for you. Better than I thought he'd be. Overall, really good prof. Tries to be funny :)
